comments.comment: For wäsokäś, suggests that Tocharian A wsokäṃ in THT 1519, plural of a putative *wsok, is related. It might plausibly be a kind of grain product. argues that *wäsok could denote a a usage of grain, a kind of dish or activity, rejecting the explanation of this word as some sort of alcoholic beverage (like in and ).
This line is written much smaller than the others and offset to the right. It was probably added in later.

comments.comment: This line is written backwards on top of the document. The word ātrai is very obscure. Ogihara apud reads it as ā[ś]rai, connecting it to Sanskrit āśraya- and explaining it as a kind of receipt. But śwasiṣṣe is usually used in front of foodstuffs. Maybe ātrai is a foodstuff?

translation.line: Income: eṃsalyī-coins of the field: seven thousand.
(In the) second (month), on day of the month three, Pernaiśe sold a picul, nine pecks mlyokotau: each for eighty (coins), (amounting to) thousand five hundred twenty.
Pernaiśe of kāsi sold a picul, five pecks mlyokotau: for seventy coins each, (amounting to) thousand and fifty.
Pore sold three piculs, four pecks highland barley: for two hundred and fifty coins each, (amounting to) eight thousand.
Pernaiśe sold a picul, seven pecks highland barley: for two hundred and fifty (coins) each, (amounting to) four thousand two hundred fifty.
I received coins as rent from Kweṃtoko for the garden of the stūpa: two thousand.
Coins for the Śiṅke-garden in Olyīśka: three thousand seven hundred.
Coins as rent of the ṣupākīñe-garden in Olyīśka: five hundred.
Coins as rent for the garden of Site of the meśiñi (?)
Coins taken for four piculs lyekśiye-millet: four thousand.
I sold three piculs lyekśiye-millet: coins: ... thousand.

comments.comment: argues that this word is derived from the prefix yn- 'in' and sāle 'earth, place', thus she glosses it as 'within the country, within the borders'. She reads it as esalyī. However, there is an anusvāra visible above the 'e'.
Ogihara apud connects this word to ṣpakīye 'pill', itself a loan word from Khotanese ṣvakye. However, the assumption of a sound change ṣp -> ṣup seems to be rather ad hoc.
It looks like the scribe first wrote pauśye, but then corrected himself.
